page.title: 08BEDGEBURY NATIONAL PINETUM
page.content: The Pinetum was established by the Forestry Commission and Kew Royal Botanic Gardens in 1925 to be a comprehensive reference collection for botanists, foresters and the public. Formerly part of Bedgebury Estate woodlands, the Pinetum was developed by Mr Dallimore of Kew up to 1950. He artistically landscaped its valleys and ridges into a botanical frame of the coniferous genera. Specimen trees of over 200 species include a Grand fir 47 m high, Kent's tallest tree. From 1950 to 1980 Mr Westall added a collection of Lawson cypress cultivars and dwarf conifers. Mr Scott has since developed an arrow trail with commentary and an information centre. Associated with the Pinetum are Forest Plots where the growth of exotic coniferous and broadleaved forest trees is studied.
